author: tio.ch
title: Contro le molestie: i locali notturni brasiliani saranno più sicuri - Ticinonline
text: Il presidente Lula ha promulgato un nuovo protocollo che permetterà di formare i dipendenti all'aiuto alle vittime BRASILIA - Il presidente del Brasile Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva ha promulgato la legge che obbliga i gestori di locali notturni ad adottare un protocollo per prevenire le molestie contro le donne e per rispondere in maniera efficace alle eventuali violenze. La legge conosciuta come "No è No" era stata approvata lo scorso agosto in parlamento. Il testo prevede che i titolari di esercizi pubblici - dove sono vendute bevande alcoliche sempre in occasione di spettacoli, concerti e gare sportive - preparino i dipendenti in modo che possano intervenire immediatamente in caso di denuncia di violenza o molestia per interrompere gli abusi e assistano la vittima nell'allertare le forze dell'ordine e nel tornare a casa - anche fornendo denaro - in sicurezza. I locali dovranno adottare inoltre un protocollo per la conservazione delle prove dei crimini, dotarsi di telecamere di videosorveglianza interne ed esterne e mettere a disposizione - segnalandolo debitamente - un telefono per le vittime. La mancata applicazione dalla legge sarà punita con una multa.

author: Pedro Henrique de Alcântara Lopes
title: Radar meteorológico para eventos extremos entrará em operação experimental em dezembro
text: O radar meteorológico, exclusivo para a Região Metropolitana de Campinas (RMC), adquirido pela Universidade Estadual de Campinas (Unicamp), em parceria com a Agência Metropolitana de Campinas (AgemCamp) – órgão que reúne os 20 municípios da RMC e com o apoio da Defesa Civil, será capaz de fazer a detecção de eventos climáticos extremos.O aparelho é capaz de realizar uma varredura horizontal, em 360º, refletindo com mais precisão horários e áreas afetadas por chuvas e tempestades. Possui alta precisão num raio de 60 km de extensão, podendo se estender por até 100 km a partir do ponto de sua instalação. As varreduras serão programadas a cada 5 a 10 minutos, com pessoas trabalhando em turnos, ou seja, durante as 24 horas do dia. O Centro será integrado aos sistemas estadual e federal de monitoramento meteorológico.Fabricado nos Estados Unidos, a antena do radar que pesa 3,5 toneladas foi instalada no dia 7 de outubro, em uma torre de 10 metros de altura. Uma operação de aproximadamente sete horas para ser finalizada. De acordo com o Centro de Pesquisas Meteorológicas e Climáticas Aplicadas à Agricultura (Cepagri) da Unicamp, a expectativa é que o aparelho comece a operar em caráter experimental em dezembro deste ano.Após entrar em funcionamento, o aparelho será capaz de monitorar a formação de eventos meteorológicos extremos, gerar alertas em tempo integral, manter o funcionamento da Rede de Alerta de Desastres, além de conseguir identificar fenômenos como microexplosões ou tornados com alta precisão, definir a velocidade em que os deslocamentos estão ocorrendo.Ao finalizar o içamento, outros equipamentos referentes à parte elétrica, de hardware e software precisarão ser montados. Um gerador a diesel será utilizado como um sistema secundário de energia. Ao fim dessa fase, virá a fase de testes, entre eles, o de conformidade e de desempenho, quando o radar será colocado para funcionar em sua capacidade máxima.Depois dos testes, virão os treinamentos tanto para a manutenção do equipamento, mais voltada para o hardware, quanto para o treinamento em software. A última fase será ao que a geração assistida, em que a empresa responsável pela instalação do radar deixará um técnico no Brasil para acompanhar o processo junto com os meteorologistas. A partir daí, o equipamento entrará em operação em caráter experimental.O que são os radares meteorológicos?Os radares meteorológicos são sensores que emitem sinais eletromagnéticos e recebem um retorno. A partir desse retorno, determinam-se as características das nuvens de chuva e tempestade. A partir do processamento desses dados, consegue-se obter uma estimativa sobre a precipitação de água –volume e intensidade – em tempo real à medida que as nuvens se formam.

author: Nathan Hutsenpiller
title: I Tried Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad and Now It’s in My Lunch Rotation
text:
I Tried Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad and Now It’s in My Lunch Rotation
With an origin dating back to 1863, one of the first amalgamations of
chicken salad was dreamed up by Liam Gray, owner of Town Meats in Wakefield, Rhode Island. His version combined leftover chicken with mayonnaise, tarragon, and grapes, and was so popular that eventually the meat market would pivot into a delicatessen. With influence like that, it’s no wonder chicken salad is still a staple in American cuisine, garnering the respect of countless chefs and celebrities alike, and somehow, never seeming to get old.
While there are plenty of variations of chicken salad to try out,
Dolly Parton — someone whose tastes are taken very seriously around here — happens to have a delicious chicken salad recipe that uses only a few ingredients, but is an absolute powerhouse. And if anyone knows the struggle of working 9 to 5 and needing an easy, yet delicious meal that can be thrown together in minutes, it’s the Queen of Country herself. So, I decided to pour myself a little cup of ambition and see what all the fuss was about with Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad. And let me tell you, I was far from disappointed.
Get the recipe:
Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad
How to Make Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad
Start by poaching your chicken in boiling water until it has reached an internal temperature of 165°F, about 10 to 12 minutes. While the chicken cools, dice your celery stalks and one small onion before adding to a large mixing bowl. Next, dice the chicken into small cubes and add to the bowl along with pecan halves, mayonnaise, and Dijon mustard. Mix everything well with a spatula.
Then using two forks, shred the chicken ensuring that you use your own discretion for how thin you want it to be. Finally, season with salt and pepper, then serve on a plate with a bed of watercress as the base.
My Honest Opinion of Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad
Growing up, I was always a ride-or-die kid when it came to mayonnaise. Regrettably, I would put mayonnaise on everything, but somewhere along the line, I slowly lost my taste for it. Because of that, I was less likely to seek out chicken salad over the years — even if it was readily available to me. It was almost to a point where I would just think that I didn’t like it anymore. Being that it’s been quite a while since I had even a bite of chicken salad, I was both excited to try Dolly’s recipe and nervous that I was making something that I would otherwise not want to finish. But boy was I wrong, because with the first bite, I was instantly met with a feeling of nostalgia and couldn’t help but finish my serving.
The only ingredient I could do without, however, was the pecans — but even that was not a deal-breaker, and I found myself eating them anyway because each bite was just that dang tasty. Though I don’t believe Dolly’s chicken salad will make me the master mayonnaise connoisseur I once was when growing up, it did remind me that I love chicken salad. And I will most certainly be adding this back into my cooking rotation.
3 Tips for Making Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad
- Don’t skip the shredding. The more you’re able to shred your chicken, the better the mayonnaise and Dijon mustard will incorporate into every crevice, leaving no dry bite in sight.
- No nuts, no problem. If you have a nut allergy, or just aren’t a fan of them in general, remove the pecans from the equation and the recipe will still be just as amazing. In my opinion, it’s the other ingredients that really tie this chicken salad together; the pecans are just a bonus.
- Adjust, taste, and repeat. While Dolly’s instructions are a fantastic guideline to follow, if you find the recipe lacking in any way, try adjusting the ingredient amounts until you like what you taste. For example, add more Dijon mustard, mix, taste, then repeat if needed.
Get the recipe:
 Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad
This post originally appeared on The Kitchn. See it there:
I Tried Dolly Parton’s Pecan Chicken Salad and It Was So Good, It’s Now in My Lunch Rotation

author: Casa e Jardim
title: Pessoas que limpam a casa são mais empáticas
text: Pesquisas comandadas pela Clorox endossam que manter a casa higienizada está relacionado com ter a mente equilibrada e com o aumento dos índices de produtividade. O relatório conduzido pela empresa de pesquisas Ketchum Global Research & Analytics analisou mais de 2 mil adultos nos Estados Unidos. De início, eles se basearam em dados já descobertos em outros estudos. Segundo a companhia de consultorias Gallup, 79% das pessoas sofrem frequentemente de estresse, enquanto o empreendimento de análise de mercado, Harris, aponta que 72% da população se sente sozinha. Com isso em pauta, eles foram investigar a relação destas informações com a limpeza dentro de casa e descobriram que a faxina frequente é uma das formas de alcançar a felicidade. Entre os entrevistados, 72% relataram melhor qualidade do sono quando dormiam em um lugar livre de sujeira, 80% sentia-se mais relaxados e 60% manifestaram uma queda nos níveis de estresse. Conforme os resultados biométricos, a felicidade dos participantes cresceu apenas pelo fato de adentrarem um lugar com a faxina em dia, permanecendo estável durante todo o tempo que eles permaneceram ali. A empatia entre os que limpavam a casa cresceu 64%. Para quem gosta de executar tarefas do lar, a felicidade era 25% maior e a disposição para ajudar o próximo ganhou um aumento de 57%. Já para os que participavam da organização da casa ainda na infância, a solidariedade era 60% maior e a empatia também equivalia a 64% mais do que aqueles que não ajudavam nas tarefas domésticas quando jovens.

author: Sentinel Staff
title: 9 SwampBats play role as North wins NECBL All-Star Game | Local Sports | keenesentinel.com
text:
WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt. — Monday was a SwampBats takeover at the New England Collegiate Baseball League All-Star Game at Upper Valley’s Maxfield Sports Complex.
The festivities, which were postponed from Sunday due to inclement weather, were full of purple and black flare, with nine SwampBats making the North Division All-Stars roster along with manager Shaun McKenna and assistant coaches Casey O’Brien and Stephen Bangs on staff.
The North Division took down the South Division in a tight 3-1 contest in front of an Upper Valley record-breaking 1,745 in attendance.
All nine Bats saw action, and outfielder Jack Herring earned the John Watterson MVP award after driving in the game’s opening run in the first inning with an RBI double.
After a dominant summer campaign, Finbar O’Brien (Newport, Gonzaga) earned the start for the South Division. Facing a tough top of the lineup, however, O’Brien gave up a leadoff walk to Ty Mainolfi (Keene, Boston College) and he was plated on Herring’s MVP-clinching double. Jaylen Hernandez (Vermont, Winthrop) made it back-to-back RBI doubles with a line drive opposite field shot, giving the North an early 2-0 lead after the first inning.
The North Division added another run in the bottom of the second, despite not recording a hit. Lead-off walks continued to plague the South, as Ryan Kolben (Sanford, UMass) and Trey King (Sanford, Georgia) reached to open the inning. A groundout placed the runners on second and third, and Brendan Sencaj (Sanford, Bentley) delivered with a hard ground ball that ate up the shortstop, extending the lead to 3-0.
Persistent pitching and stout defense were the themes for the rest of the game. While the South Division finished with six hits, one more than the North, they could not string anything together outside of the top of the fifth on a Kyle Branch (Oklahoma, Newport) single, a Garrett Larsen (Yale, Danbury) hit by pitch, and an RBI single from Sebastian Mexico (Louisiana Tech, Valley). Team South also failed to capitalize on a bases-loaded opportunity in the eighth after two walks and a hit by pitch.
Todd Kniebbe (Keene, Kansas State) shut down the South Division in the top of the ninth in a 1-2-3 inning to earn the victory and pick up the save. However, the bottom of the ninth was still played to accommodate the reserves and showcase their talents in front of the scouts. During this extra play, the North had the bases loaded but could not add to its lead.
The North Division sees Keene sit comfortably in first with a 26-11 record, with the second-place Sanford Mainers 7.5 games back at 18-18. The North Adams SteepleCats (16-18) and All-Star Game host Upper Valley Nighthawks (15-19) round out the current playoff picture, but the North Shore Navigators (14-20) and Vermont Mountaineers (13-24) are not out of it yet.
The South Division is much more competitive, with the Bristol Blues (24-12), Newport Gulls (21-14), and Martha’s Vineyard Sharks (21-16) all within four games of first place. The Mystic Schooners (17-20), Valley Blue Sox (16-19), Ocean State Waves (15-20), and Danbury Westerners (14-19) are currently battling for fourth place and the final playoff spot as the 2025 regular season nears a close.
Here’s how each SwampBat did in the NECBL All-Star Game:
Ben Rabatin (Kent State) got the start on the mound for the North, securing the win in his inning of work. Rabatin worked into some trouble, but pitched out of it as he struck out two batters.
In the bottom half of the first inning, Ty Mainolfi (Boston College) led off for the North with a walk. After advancing to second on a groundout, Jack Herring (East Carolina) was set up for an RBI knock, bringing Mainolfi in.
Mainolfi was 0-for-2 with a walk, strikeout and a run scored. Herring finished 1-for-3 with a double and two strikeouts.
Marshal Lipsey (Florida Atlantic) drew a pair of walks.
Ripken Reese (Kent State), who represented the SwampBats in the home run derby prior to the game (hitting 3 home runs), recorded a hit in his only plate appearance.
Michael O’Brien (Arkansas-Little Rock) and Nick Romano (Florida Atlantic) each came on off the bench in the game, and each went 0-for-2 with a strikeout.
Swanzey native Ben Dean (Duke) came in for relief in the sixth inning and allowed three straight base runners, but didn’t allow any damage to come of it after striking out two straight to end the inning.
Closer Todd Kniebbe (Kansas State) shut the door with the save in the ninth. He was the third SwampBats pitcher to make an appearance and not allow a run. Kniebbe struck out two batters as he retired the side in order.

author: VNExplorer
title: Lluvias y una vigilancia de inundaciones en el sur de Florida: pronóstico y radar del tiempo
text:
Miami Hialeah, Florida, W 16th Avenue, flooding after heavy rain, cars splashing. (Photo by: Jeffrey Greenberg/Universal Images Group via Getty Images)
Un viernes con mucha agua es lo que espera el sur de Florida, que tendrá períodos de lluvias y tormentas que se mantendrán al menos hasta la tarde del sábado.
Se esperan acumulados de agua que pudieran alcanzar entre 2 a 5 pulgadas, con acumulados localizados que pudieran incluso ser mayores.
Por esta razón tenemos una vigilancia de inundaciones hasta las 8:00 p.m. del sábado para los condados Broward y Miami-Dade.
El viento será protagonista también alcanzando en ráfagas hasta 40 mph, por lo que además tendremos una advertencia por viento desde el mediodía de hoy hasta la noche del sábado.
Recuerde además que durante hoy y mañana sábado tendremos posibilidad de que las tormentas que se formen puedan llegar a ser severas, siendo capaces de generar algún tornado aislado y vientos de hasta 60 mph.
El domingo estará mejorando el panorama con algo de viento fuerte todavía.
[wx-radar /]

author: Oliver Rodzianko
title: Rigetti Computing: Huang Pops The Quantum Bubble
text:
Nothing shows respect in the markets for a business leader like his comments causing a stock's price to crash nearly 50% in 24 hours. Indeed, this is precisely what happened to Rigetti Computing, Inc. (
Rigetti Computing: Huang Pops The Quantum Bubble
Summary
- Rigetti Computing, Inc.’s speculative valuation, with a pre-crash P/S ratio of 250, led to a nearly 50% price drop after Nvidia’s CEO highlighted quantum computing’s distant scalability (~20 years away).
- Quantum computing's potential is revolutionary, but Rigetti's fundamentals don’t justify even a post-crash P/S of 130. Significant dilution and speculative sentiment further weaken its investment case.
- Fair value estimate of $595M (P/S ~50) highlights a negative -69.5% margin of safety. Avoid Rigetti stock despite short-term momentum appeal; its growth timeline and financial risks remain speculative.
Analyst’s Disclosure: I/we have a beneficial long position in the shares of NVDA either through stock ownership, options, or other derivatives. I wrote this article myself, and it expresses my own opinions. I am not receiving compensation for it (other than from Seeking Alpha). I have no business relationship with any company whose stock is mentioned in this article.
